name: Mitchell
comment info:
What do you notice?
    - The first thing that stood out to me is that none of the percentages add up to 100%. The next thing I notice is that a lot of the L.G.B.T.Q community come from later generations. And more of them are liberal than moderate or conservatives.

For instance gay marriage is legalized now which is huge. Possibly gives people still in the closest as a worry for them. To now come out and accept who they are. 
    
    How does this relate to you and your community?

name: Leandro Ramdin
comment info:
1. I noticed that the majority of LGBTQ people identified are those of younger generations and have a tendency to be on the more liberal side.
    2. I wonder if this increase is directly or indirectly related to the rise of social media in recent years.
    3. This relates to m and my community as they're continually increasing numbers of people identifying as LGBTQ among young teens from 7-12 grade.
    4. The rise of the LGBTQ seen with our own eyes.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Leandro Ramdin I never thought about the idea that social media could be a main reason that more people are coming out as LGBTQ. And I feel like you are right too. The limit to privacy since social media has became a thing has gotten small and small.

name: Kaiden
comment info:
The younger the respondent is, the more likely they are to identify as L.G.B.T.Q. Similarly, liberals are more likely to identify as L.G.B.T.Q., when compared to moderates and conservatives, by a decent amount.
    
    I wonder, while it may not be a large number of respondents as the whole group ranges from ages 18 to 79+, but maybe looking at those still in college would alter the final numbers a bit? From the looks of it, the largest demographic who identify as L.G.B.T.Q. are Gen Z who range from 18-27. The average age to earn a bachelor’s degree is 22-24 years old. So realistically, a large portion of Gen Z is still in school. 
    
    While this graph does not in any way represent any data on rates of homophobia or the like, I cannot help but see potential correlations with the low identification rates in older generations and the public shaming and violence towards queer individuals I’ve witnessed. If the trend we see in younger age demographics showing higher rates of L.G.B.T.Q. identification continues or even stagnates, I think there is a good chance for change in the future. While any population quickly moving from a small 2 percent minority to a more prominent 23 percent is bound to shake up things, I can only hope it eventually brings about more understanding and acceptance. 
    
    Shifting Identities: Generational and Ideological Gaps in L.G.B.T.Q. Identification

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Kaiden --
    
    Great wonderings.  I wonder if the data includes the age, as well as the age band.  Based on your wondering, this may tell us about the relationship between age and year entering the teens has on self-identifying as LGBTQ+.  Was there is turning point year?  
    
    Also, I wonder if there will be a large change in statistics in next year's LGBTQ+ survey.

name: Kaliah
comment info: I notice that most people who identify as LGBTQ are Gen Z and it makes me wonder if it's because our generation grew up with more of the resources and technology that we see and these apps where we follow people and trends especially on TikTok with so many influencers who share their stories and try to help people find who they are similar to. This relates to my community because I am gen Z. "Love is love for Gen Z".

replies.name: K

@Kaliah
    I think the idea that there may be a correlation between technology and social media use and higher identification rates is really interesting! Often times, when communities tend to be more homogenous, it makes it harder for individuals to accept their own differences, let alone find acceptance within their communities. I definitely think that the community building social media encourages can aid in someone being more comfortable and accepting of identifying as part of the LGBTQ community.

name: It starts at the top
comment info: In every generation, including mine, youth are endlessly seeking attention and their own identity apart from previous one, and at times rebellion to their parents. Social media provides a global scale dopamine hit of approval that in previous generations was limited to localized social environments, particularly school. Is identifying as LGBTQ+ akin to shaving one’s head to support a friend/family member who’s lost their hair to cancer treatment, or is deeper?

name: LJ
comment info:
I notice a significant increase over time with the percentage of U.S adults identifying as LGBTQ+, going from 2% in the Silent Generation to 23% in Generation Z. 
    
    I wonder if the location affects whether someone identifies as LGBTQ+, as well as what has caused the significant increase in LGBTQ+ identification, and will it continue to rise.
    
    This relates to me and my community as it shows a clear national increase in LGBTQ+ identification that’ll be present and visible in my own community.
    
    “The Shining Rainbow: Gen Z leading by 23%!”

name: Moderator Chris
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.  Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  
    
    Two headlines from Perth Amboy, N.J. -- “Generation Pride: A Demographic Portrait of LGBTQ+ America" by Daniel and "Rising Acceptance: Trends in LGBTQ+ Self-Identification Among U.S. Adults" by Esmeily;  
    
    Three headlines by Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Convent Station, N.J. --  “Out of the Shadows: The LGBTQ+ Community Around Us” by Juliana, “Pride Peaks with Gen Z” by Giulia and “Society and its LGBTQ+ Makeup” by Whitney 
    
    “Be Unique, Be You: Shocking Statistics About LGBTQ+” by Jasmine of N.Y. and “New Generation, New Voices:  LGBTQ+ Identity on the Rise Across the U.S.” by Dominick of Valley Stream, N.Y.
     
    Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article, a summary of the article, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graphs and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graph and where you can find them in the graph.
     
    The next graph will be released by Friday, May 2.  The topic will be about what we think about what we eat. 
     
    Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who has had students who are each of L., G., B., T., Q. and +, and Chris Luzniak of Columbus, Ohio, who is full of joy (one might say gay!) at all the wonderful comments he got to read today!

name: Scarlett
comment info: I notice that in the graph it shows that the more younger generations (Z and millennials), identify as LGBTQ vs the older generations whose rates are much lower. I also notice that most of the people that identify in the LGBTQ group are liberals. I also noticed that the highest percentage of the LGBTQ associated people live in cities. This makes sense to me because usually, most of the big cities in our country are mostly democratic (liberal). I wonder if identifying as LGBTQ was not as popular back years ago,  due to the fact most of the older generations do not identify as LGBTQ in the chart. I also wonder if COVID had any effect on the younger people identifying in the LGBTQ group, due to lots of people changing aspects about themselves during quarantine. This relates to me and my community because I am a part of gen-Z, so it is interesting to see how the LGBTQ population is pretty high for my generation.                                                                       Catchy Headline: LGBTQ rates across the generations

name: SophiaAOSE
comment info:
This graph displays the percentages of people who identify as LGBTQ+ by certain demographics. I noticed that most people who openly identify as being part of this community are part of Generation Z. Along with this, people who identify as liberal are also more likely to be part of this community. This makes sense because people who align more with a conservative ideology are more likely to be against homosexuality. Finally, people who live in more urban areas are more likely to be homosexual. I wonder what the statistics will be for the upcoming generation. By the recent trends, I predict it will increase. This impacts my community because I live in the suburbs and there is not as big as a community in my area. This could be negative for people part of this community. 
    Headline: LGBTQ+ Community Graphed

replies.comment info: @SophiaAOSE - Thanks for sharing. Can you say more about why you think "people who live in more urban areas are more likely to be homosexual"?

replies.name: S

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @SophiaAOSE I find what you said about your community interesting. Why do you think that would be a negative?

name: Eleanor AOSE
comment info:
After looking at the graph, I noticed that it compares the number of adults who identify as LGBTQ by age, ideology, locale, and education. I also noticed that younger generations have increasingly higher percentages of people who identify as LGBTQ than older generations. For example, 2% of the Silent Generation identifies as LGBTQ, while 23% of Generation Z identifies as LGBTQ. Individuals with liberal ideologies have a much higher rate of people identifying as LGBTQ than moderates or conservatives. The data displayed under locale and education is very similar. 
    After looking at the graph, I wonder why such a large percentage of Generation Z identifies as LGBTQ as compared to other generations. What might data with similar comparisons look like in the future?
    This graph relates to my community as the number of adults who identify as LGBTQ has increased from 3.5% in 2012 to 9.3% in 2024.   
    A headline for the graph is “The Incline in LGBTQ Identification”.

replies.comment info: @Eleanor AOSE - Good summary of key points. Any guesses at why the data is so different between generations (and not when looking at education or locale)?

name: Victoria AOSE
comment info:
The age and political ideology heavily correlate with the likelihood of LGBTQ identification. The older the generation, the lower LGBTQ identification. For example, the silent generation has 2% of LGBTQ identification, whereas generation Z has 23%.  I noticed that 21% of liberals are LGBTQ, whereas 3% of conservatives identify as LGBTQ. I think this graph is getting readers to analyze why there is such a vast difference between LGBTQ identification in political parties and age. For instance, based on my understanding of politics, I know conservatives favor traditional values.Throughout the time of society when the Silent Generation and Baby Boomer generation took place, the traditional values of the United States were not accepting of the LGBTQ community. This provides a possible explanation for why older generations and conservatives are less likely to identify as LGBTQ. It also influences people to decide if the exposure to LGBTQ communities influences kids today to be a part of the community. Or is it acceptance that influences people to be themselves? I wonder if people of earlier ages were less likely to identify as LGBTQ because it wasn't accepted or they weren't exposed to it. This graph relates to me and my community because I have some friends and a cousin who identify as part of the LGBTQ community. I think it is essential to understand how politics and age tie into identification to better understand my peers. 
    Headline: What influences LGBTQ identification today?

replies.comment info: @Victoria AOSE - you raise a great question about what may have a bigger influence on the changes: acceptance or exposure. What do you think has a bigger influence? Is there a way we could study this?

name: Ciara AOSE
comment info:
The first thing I noticed upon looking at this graph is how Generation Z and Millennials identify as LGBTQ+ significantly more than previous generations. I also noticed that those who identify as LGBTQ+ tend to be more progressive, as they are typically liberal rather than conservative. How truly accurate are the statistics on Generation Z? The context suggests that this graph represents US adults, so how would it change if it also included Gen Z teenagers? Would Gen Z’s percentage of 23% rise or fall? I also wonder if the rise of social media has impacted identification with the LGBTQ+ community. With social media, there has been increased acceptance and education about the LGBTQ+ community, so Gen Z and Millennials may be significantly more likely to identify as LGBTQ+ because they are more likely to be accepted. This relates to my community because, as a member of Generation Z, it is fascinating to see how people my age identify themselves.
    Headline: The Different Types of People in the LGBTQ+ Community.

replies.comment info: @Ciara AOSE - Good noticings! And good questions about GenZ. What do you think would make that data more accurate?

name: Giovana AOSE
comment info:
Headline: "LGBTQ+ Pride Grows with the New Generation"
    
    The graph depicts the rates of LGBTQ identification in the U.S. based on age, ideology, location, and education. The first thing I noticed is that Generation Z and Millennials have the highest rates of LGBTQ identification at 23% and 14%. I also noticed that education doesn't really affect identification. I didn't expect location to be a factor however, it is. I wonder if LGBTQ identification rates can drop or rise based on the political ideology of the president.  Also, I wonder which specific year LGBTQ identification rates started to rise and if they will keep rising or may fall as younger generations get older. This relates to me and my community because I am part of Generation Z, which has the highest rate of LGBTQ identification. I have started to see more openness and acceptance of the LGBTQ community in my town, on social media, etc.

replies.name: V

This is because a person's level of education does not directly influence their emotional state. Rather, social norms and values influence this, as the graph shows.

name: Whitney AOSE
comment info:
The first thing that I noticed was the LGBTQ identification by age, with Generation Z at 23%.  As the generations get older, the percentage of people who are a part of the LGBTQ community decrease, with the Silent Generation at 2%.  I also noticed the difference between Liberal and Conservative ideology, with 21% liberals and 3% Conservatives.  Looking at the data on the graph, the next generation is likely to have a percentage higher than 23% of people who identify as LGBTQ.  The locale and education columns are similar in percentage, while the greatest differences lie within age and ideology.  The time period definitely has an impact on the results of the graph.  I wonder how much of an impact location would have on this graph, and it would be interesting to see what the results would be.  I wonder if the percentages of the older generations would be higher if they were to grow up in a time period similar to today.  This relates to me and my community because I am a part of Generation Z and this graph helps me understand my community and ideology of those around me.
    Headline: Society and its LGBTQ Makeup

name: Andres Castaneda
comment info:
1.) I notice that in certain categories such as age or ideology, one category of person identifies with the LGBTQ+ more than other groups in that category, however in other categories such as locale or education, the variation between the groups is little to none. I notice that in age, as the generations get older, the percentage of that generation that identifies with the LGBTQ+ decreases, however this can be to other variables. Lastly, I notice that around a quarter of generation Z identify with the LGBTQ+ and around a fifth of liberals identify with LGBTQ+ as well.
    
    2.) I wonder why certain demographics have large variations between the groups in those demographics, and why others don't have as great of variation? I wonder why there is a trend in generation where there is a decrease in people who identify with the LGBTQ+ as people get older? Lastly, I wonder why so many people in generation Z and those who identify as liberals identify themselves with LGBTQ+?
    
    3.) This relates to me and my community because as mentioned in the short article below, the number of adults in the United States who identify with the LGBTQ+ is around 9.6%, which is an increase of around 3.5% since 2012. There is a general increase that as things become more normalized and are shunned less in society, that people will not be afraid or nervous to come out as much because of the lessened stigma around that group.
    
    4.) A New Age in Identity! LGBTQ+ Identification by Generation and Political Position!

replies.comment info: @Andres Castaneda - good notice and wonderings! You mention in #1 that the smaller percentage in older generations could be a result of other variables. Any guesses on what those could include? Could you find or come up with a few?

replies.name: H
replies.comment info: @Andres Castaneda, I like how you acknowledged the division between LGBTQ identification between liberals and conservatives. I wonder if that kind of ideology will ever shift.

name: Lavon
comment info:

    I noticed that Gen Z has the highest percentage of LGBTQ people compared to the other generations. I also noticed that in Ideology, liberals have the highest percentage.

replies.comment info: @Lavon - good thoughts! I really like your question in #2. And I think it relates to some of your ideas in #1. When you say "Gen Z has the highest percentage of LGBTQ people", does that mean other generations had less LGBTQ people? How does the way people determine where they fit in this affect things?

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Lavon I like your title! If your 'wonder' is based off of how this information was gathered, I am also curious! Maybe it was based off of if someone identifies as any of the five letters of LGBTQ, or maybe it was whether or not they identify as heterosexual and/or cisgender!

name: Jackie AOSE
comment info:
1. I noticed that a significant amount of Generation Z self identifies as a part of the LGBTQ+ compared to other generations. I believe that this is because younger generations are more exposed to different possible sexual and gender identities than older generations because of the the spread of information via social media. This logic tracks because millennials, the second youngest generation in this data, have the second highest percentage of LGBTQ identification and the oldest, the Silent Generation, has the lowest percentage. Furthermore, Liberals are more likely to identify as LGBTQ that conservatives. This is likely because the liberal belief system has more favorable policies on gay marriage. Though the percentages are pretty close, the least amount of people identify as LGBTQ in rural areas. This reflects the Ideology section of the graph because most people in rural areas lean conservative. A similar percentage of graduates and non-graduates identify as LGBTQ, suggesting education has little influence on sexual orientation. 
     2. I wonder if the trend in the age graph will continue into Generation Alpha, the next youngest generation. I wonder what career has the highest percent of LGBTQ people. What affect does family ideology have on a person's sexual identity?
    3. This relates to me because I am a part of Generation Z so this graph helps me better understand my community.
    4.  "Identifying Identities: How the L.G.B.T.Q. makes up our Nation"

replies.comment info: @Jackie AOSE - Great notice and wonderings! I am really intrigued by your questions around family ideology. Does anything in the data make you ask that?

replies.name: V
replies.comment info: @Jackie AOSE Nice comment! I like how you said that exposure to the LGBTQ community has led to the rise in people who identify as part of it. I've observed the same trend! But the community's growing acceptance may also explain why more people identify. It's unclear if older generations didn't identify as LGBTQ or if they still feel shame and repression from their upbringing. Both increased exposure and a more accepting community could be contributing factors to the increase in LGBTQ individuals in younger generations.

replies.name: H
replies.comment info: @Jackie AOSE, I appreciate how you mentioned the spread of information through the media. Do you think that if this graph were created in the past, it would be completely different? Or does the trend of the newer generation being more open to change, consistent with the past?

name: Melanny p3
comment info:
I observe that the highest rates of LGBTQ+ identification are found among Generation Z, liberals, urban residents, urban residents, and those without college degrees. The most notable differences are related to age and political beliefs—such as, 23% of Gen Z individuals identify as LGBTQ+, whereas only 2% of those from the Silent Generation do. Similarly, 21% of liberals identify as LGBTQ+ compared to just 3% of conservatives.
    I wonder if younger generations are more likely to identify this way because they receive greater support from social media, schools, and peer groups. Perhaps older individuals might have identified similarly if they had grown up during a more accepting era. I also consider whether some people might still hesitate to openly identify as LGBTQ+ due to safety concerns, especially in conservative or rural areas. 
    Family expectations, religious beliefs, or fear of judgment could be preventing some from being fully honest. It’s noteworthy that there’s only a 1% difference between college graduates and non-graduates, which makes me curious about why education doesn’t seem to have a stronger influence here. Additionally, I wonder if these figures will continue to evolve as society becomes more accepting. For Generation Z, identifying as LGBTQ+ feels quite normalized, largely thanks to social media, but acceptance still varies greatly depending on one’s location and community attitudes.
    The different group in our society.

replies.comment info: @Melanny p3 - Great ideas! Thank you for sharing. You bring up a good point that "some people might still hesitate to openly identify as LGBTQ+". Any ideas on how this may affect the data? Or how to get around this?

HI, @Melanny p3 --
    
    Did I just read a very similar response in Lily of AOSE’s response that was posted an hour before yours?  This is what I replied to her:  
    
    You write, “I also wonder if some people still aren’t being fully honest because they don’t feel safe, especially in conservative or rural areas.”  This is called response bias.  Bias caused by who asks the questions, how the questions are asked and whether people are not truthful.  You may want to investigate how the survey was done to see if there are other sources of response bias.  Here’s the link --https://www.gallup.com/175307/gallup-poll-social-series-methodology.aspxHow about you examine the methodology and find other possible response bias.

name: Giulia AOSE
comment info:
Headline: Pride Peaks with Gen Z
    What do I notice?
    This graph shows different demographics of U.S. adults and how many identify as LGBTQ. From first looking at this graph, I notice that the age group that most identifies as LGBTQ is Generation Z. The ideology that most identifies as liberal. There isn't a big difference regarding factors like locale or education. As generations get older, fewer identify as LGBTQ, most likely because they tend to hold more conservative views. 
    
    What do I wonder? 
    I wonder why LGBTQ+ identification might decrease with age. Does LGBTQ acceptance in certain areas or families influence these percentages? Conservatives tend to be less supportive of same-sex marriage, so maybe people whose families are strongly conservative may not say they identify as LGBTQ so they aren't judged. Why might identification rates be similar between college graduates and non-graduates?
    
    How does this relate to you and your community?
    This is related to me and my community because I'm from Generation X and have noticed that people my age are much more open about identifying as LGBTQ. My grandparents are much more conservative and are not as open and accepting of the LGBTQ community. I'm from NJ, which is a liberal state that is near a large city, so more people may identify as LGBTQ.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Giulia AOSE --
    
    Great headline.  It’s pretty amazing that almost a quarter of Gen Z identify as LGBTQ+.  
    
    In the coming decade, do you think that the Gen Z percentage who identify as LGBTQ+ will increase, decrease or stay the same?  Since the Gallup surveys on LGBTQ+ go back to 2012, you may find evidence about what happens to people as they age regarding identifying as LGBTQ+.

replies.name: T
replies.comment info: @Giulia AOSE I like your headline. I feel like it really describes what is going on in the graph.

name: Veronica AOSE
comment info:
I noticed that this is a graph depicting the percentage of U.S adults who self identify as something other than heterosexual. The groups with the greater percentages are from generation Z, liberal, from cities, and nongraduates. 
    I wonder how this poll was conducted. I also wonder if people who are not out were asked. Would they not want to answer truthfully? This would lead to an accuracy of percentages.  I am curious as to how these other identifiable groups play into how you identify. Does it really matter where you are from if this is something you feel on the inside? 
    This relates to me and my community because rates of people identifying as LGBTQ+ are on the rise. I also live near NYC which is a big city, so that might be a factor. 
    Headline: Rates of people identifying as LGBTQ+

replies.name: J
replies.comment info:
@Veronica AOSE
    I also was wondering about the accuracy, maybe they went into communities prominently LGBTQ compared to normal.

name: Lily AOSE
comment info:
I notice that the most LGBTQ+ identification happens among Gen Z, liberals, people living in cities, and non-graduates. The biggest differences are by age and ideology—like, 23% of Gen Z identify as LGBTQ+, but only 2% of the Silent Generation do. And when it comes to beliefs, 21% of liberals identify that way compared to just 3% of conservatives. I wonder if younger generations identify more as LGBTQ+ because they have more support from social media, schools, and their peers. Maybe older people would’ve identified more too if they had grown up in a more accepting time. I also wonder if some people still aren’t being fully honest because they don’t feel safe, especially in conservative or rural areas. Family expectations, religion, or fear of judgment could be holding people back. It’s interesting that there’s barely any difference between college grads and non-grads—just 1%—which makes me wonder why education doesn’t seem to affect this much. I’m also curious if these numbers will keep changing in the next few years as society becomes more open. Being a part of the Gen Z community, people identifying as LGBTQ+ feels normalized, especially because of social media, but it still depends a lot on where you live and how accepting the people around you are.
    
    Headline: Generation Gap: How Age and Politics Affect LGBTQ+ Identification"

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @Lily AOSE --
    
    You write, “I also wonder if some people still aren’t being fully honest because they don’t feel safe, especially in conservative or rural areas.”  
    
    This is called response bias.  Response bias is caused by who asks the questions, how the questions are asked and whether people are not truthful. 
    
     You may want to look into how the survey was done to see if there are other sources of response bias.  Here’s the link --https://www.gallup.com/175307/gallup-poll-social-series-methodology.aspx

name: Addison AOSE
comment info: The first thing I observed is that LGBTQ identification is higher in newer generations like Gen-Z and Millennials compared to older generations. Second, LGBTQ identification is much more common in those who follow Liberal ideology compared to Conservatives. Finally, this identification is also slightly more prevalent in non college graduates. I am curious how the introduction of social media to newer generations may have impacted these statistics. The biggest difference I can think of between older/newer generations is the access to different forms of media. I also wonder how these graphs will change in this coming year as these statistics came from 2024. I believe they will increase as we can see there has been a slight increase every year these statistics were taken. I also wonder how introducing European/South American countries would impact these statistics? This impacts me because I live near NYC and as the graph explains, there is a high percentage of LGBTQ identification in cities. This graph also shows how more and more people are beginning to identify in the manor and therfore, more groups, protests, and clubs may start popping up to support this growing group.

replies.comment info:

    Thank you for your thorough set of noticings and wonderings.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Today’s graphs are about the demographics (or, characteristics) of the U.S. adults who self-identify as LGBTQ+.
    
    From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online for the four questions.  If you include a claim, please back it up with evidence that supports your claim.  By Friday morning, we’ll give shout outs for some of the catchiest headlines and more.  
    
    You can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  
    
    The next graph and final graph of this school year will be released by Friday, May 2.  The topic will be about what we think about what we eat.

name: Daniel Vasquez
comment info:
Observations - There is increasing LGBTQ+ identification in younger generations (Gen Z & Millennials) compared to older generations (Gen X & the Silent Generation). Due to growing societal acceptance, legal protections for LGBTQ+ individuals over time, and the impact of the internet and social media. LGBTQ+ identification seems to be higher in urban and suburban areas compared to rural areas. Politically, more LGBTQ+ individuals identify as liberal compared to moderates and conservatives. Education level (like in college graduate vs non-graduate) also shows a minimal difference in LGBTQ+ identification. 
    
    Questions - How strong is the link between increased internet/social media usage and higher rates of self-identification among younger generations? I also wonder how many individuals still feel unable to come out, and how that would impact the overall statistics if they did. What were the challenges and experiences of older generations in understanding and expressing their LGBTQ+ identities without modern technology and with greater social stigma?
    
    Relation to Community - In NJ, where there are many urbanized areas, which also points to the increased acceptance of LBGTQ+ in the state. This suggests that LGBTQ+ issues and identities are becoming more visible and openly discussed among younger people in NJ communities. There is also the Garden State Equality organization which advocates for  LGBTQ+. 
    
    Headline - "Generation Pride: A Demographic Portrait of LGBTQ+ America"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Daniel Vasquez --
    
    GREAT noticings and wonderings.  
    
    You write, “How strong is the link between increased internet/social media usage and higher rates of self-identification among younger generations?”  How could you test this hypothesis?  It may involve finding published datasets or doing a survey.  
    
    Please share with us your plan.

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @Daniel Vasquez Your question about the link between internet/social media usage and higher rates of self-identification among younger generations is great! It makes sense that because Generation Z has been exposed to the internet so much more, they are therefore more open and comfortable with the LGBTQ community.

replies.name: W
replies.comment info: @Daniel Vasquez - Great point about the Garden State Equality organization.  That definitely helps New Jersey citizens learn more about their community.

name: Juliana AOSE
comment info: This graph shows the percentage of people in the US who are a part of the LGBTQ community by generation. Along with this, it displays their ideology, locale, and education. Firstly, I noticed that Gen Z had the highest percentage of LGBT identification and that a majority of them agreed with the liberal ideology. The conservative ideology is the least popular for this community to identify with as well. I also noticed that the locale and education graphs had similar percentages within each one. I wonder if these factors, like education and locale, play a big part in people’s LGBT identification. I also wonder if other people from the older generations are a part of the community, but have not come out and if this would drastically change the percentages.This relates to me and my community because it displays how more people are being exposed to the LGBTQ community and can expand their knowledge on the topic. A title could be: “Out of the shadows: the LGBTQ community around us.”

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @Juliana AOSE I also think that more people from older generations have not come out as identifying as LGBTQ because when they were growing up, it was not as socially acceptable. More data on this would make the percentages more accurate.

name: Kelsey
comment info: I noted that Gen Z has the highest percentage of people that identify as LGBTQ and that these people tend to hold more liberal views, almost 20% more than conservative views. As you work back through the generations, the percentage of people who identify as LGBTQ gets less and less. Locale doesn't seem to have an impact and same with education. The percentage of people in cities, suburbs, and rural areas doesn't show a trend in identification. This is the same for education with gradutes or nongraduates. I wonder if there any of this information can combine to find the most common combination of the data explored here. Like does living in a city and graduating mean more people identify as LGBTQ or are all of these data points separate? I also wonder if the reason for the percentage decreases as the generations get older is because this wasn't an accepted concept then or if there is another maybe biological reason for this shift. This realtes to by community because I have noticed more people that identify as LGBTQ who are closer to by age, so Gen Z rather than people who Gen X. It is becoming a more accpeted and welcomed idea, which is shown in this data. I would title this graph: Generational Identity-The Affect of Generation on LGBTQ Identity

replies.comment info:
HI, @Kelsey --
    
    What you are discussing in your wonderings is the crosstabs.  
    
    Crosstabs, short for cross tabulations, is a statistical method used to analyze relationships between two or more categorical variables.
    
    Search online for the 2025 Gallup poll on LGBTQ+.  There, you will find more information on the results and the methodology -- but not the crosstabs.  I have requested them from Gallup.

name: William
comment info: This  sort of poll is misleading because it lumps together all nontraditional categories (LGBTQ+) into one group, so we don’t know the breakdown of each separate category. I notice that younger people often identify as queer or bi even though their actual sexual behavior is primarily heterosexual; I’d guess that the largest part of the increased reporting among the youngest generation comes from that phenomenon, but we can’t say without a more refined poll.

replies.comment info:
HI, @William --
    
    You are asking for the crosstabs which displays statistics by category.  (Crosstabs -- short for cross tabulations, is a statistical method used to analyze relationships between two or more categorical variables.)
    
    Search online for the 2025 Gallup poll on LGBTQ+.  There, you will find more information on the results and the methodology -- but not the crosstabs.  I have requested them from Gallup.

HI, @Dominick Rios --

There you may get more insight as to “why the percentage of adults from older generation that identify as part of the LGBTQ+ community is so much smaller than in the more recent generations.”  It may have to do with events that may have affected the percentage of U.S. adults who identify as LGBTQ+.

name: Dominick C
comment info:
I noticed that more U.S. adults are identifying as LGBTQ+ compared to previous years. Younger generations, especially those just entering adulthood, are significantly more likely to identify as something other than heterosexual. Bisexual identity appears to be the most commonly reported among LGBTQ+ individuals.

name: Mohammed Khan

    You wonder about the percentage of each age group which identifies as LGBTQ+ seems reasonable.  But, why do you think there is a significant 9 percentage point increase for Millennials (1981 – 1996) to Generation Z (1997 – 2006)?

name: Jared P
comment info: I notice that the more recent the generation, the more people identify as part of the LGBTQ community. This may be due to the growing acceptance of LGBTQ in society in recent history. I wonder why there is such a significant difference between the proportion of LGBTQ who are liberal compared to other political views. This relates to my community because I know many people who are part of the LGBTQ community. A title for this graph could be “LGBTQ In Action”.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Jared P --
    
    You write, “I notice that the more recent the generation, the more people identify as part of the LGBTQ community. This may be due to the growing acceptance of LGBTQ in society in recent history.”  But, couldn’t older adults who hadn’t identified with LGBTQ+ in the past, now identify to a pollster that they self-identify as LGBTQ+?

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Jared P I agree that more people in younger generations identify as LGBTQ.

name: Rainelys Francisco
comment info:
- What do you notice? 
    I noticed that many of the people who identify themselves as part of the LGBTQ+ are from recent generations, while the older generations have a significant decrease instead. I personally think that this is caused by the laws that the government made legal to protect LGBTQ+ rights through out the many years and give them more ability to do various things regardless of personal identification, since it is known that older generations couldn't openly show what they truly identify as due to the discrimination that was faced. I also noticed that they also mostly live in cities instead of rural/private areas. 
    - What do you wonder?
    I wonder what specific laws have changed to cause such a high increase in LGBTQ+ percentage, aside from making more open rights. I wonder how their views differ based of mere ideology, how does liberal and conservative differ? Lastly, I wonder why it is that most of the LGBTQ+ are non-graduate,  how does it correlate?  
    - How does this relate to you and your community?
    This relates to many communities, all genders and all people. Since queer rights increased, we have a clearer understanding on the statistics that may have caused more acceptance, helping those who don't feel comfortable in expressing their true selves be more open. 
    -Headline:
     "Live, Laugh, Love And Be Queer!"

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Rainelys Francisco I also do wonder why most of the LGBTQ+ are non-graduates. Could it associate with the statistics of the higher percentage of Generation Z people coming out. Could it be because non-graduates do not feel accepted, or comfortable in both their school and community. I also wonder what specific laws have changed to cause such a high increase in LGBTQ+ percentage.

name: Johan P3
comment info:
1)LGBTQ identification is highest among younger generations, with 23% of Generation Z and 14% of Millennials identifying as such, compared to only 2–5% among older generations. Political ideology shows a similar pattern, as 21% of liberals identify as LGBTQ, versus just 8% of moderates and 3% of conservatives. Location also plays a role, with higher identification rates in cities (11%) than in suburbs (10%) or rural areas (7%). Interestingly, education level shows little impact, with similar rates among college graduates (9%) and nongraduates (10%).
    2)What factors contribute to the stark difference in LGBTQ identification between liberals and conservatives?
    3)New Jersey is also a state that is mostly urban and suburban with a basically liberal population, especially in cities like Newark, Jersey City, and North and Central Jersey. From the chart, people who live in cities and identify as liberal are more likely to identify themselves as LGBTQ
    4)"The Future Is Queer: Inside Gen Z’s Bold New World"

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Johan P3 I also live in New Jersey and I didn't think of this graph in terms of the locale here. That is very true and a great observation. Do you think that if there was a graph showing the percentage of people who identify as LGBTQ by state, New Jersey would be close to the top?

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Johan P3 I also noticed these things as well! I liked your wonder as it wasn't something I thought about when I first looked at the graph.

name: Dialeski Per 3
comment info:
1. I notice that Gen Z is most of the LGBT population based off of age, and there tends to be less identifying with the LGBT the more you go down the list of earlier generations. Out of locale, LGBT identifying people are more prevalent in cities, and as for education there's almost no difference. Education must not really have an impact on someone's connection to the LGBT community, and neither does the location.  
    2. I wonder why education may not have an impact on whether or not someone identifies with the LGBTQ. I as well wonder why location doesn't majorly impact the identification of someone as well.
    3. This relates to my community and I because I feel a lot of people in my community, more specifically high schoolers my age, have been tending to identify with the LGBT community. It has also become less of a thing to be ashamed of, compared to—let's say the 60's to 70's, and even before then. 
    HEADLINE: Many Voices, One Community: Diversity Within the LGBTQ+ Community

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Dialeski Per 3 I too wonder why the location of where people live don't affect someone's identification as much. I feel that where someone lives is dependent on if they are open about their sexuality or not. Some areas are less accepting of someone's sexuality because of traditional values. Usually, it is mostly people in rural areas which is portrayed in the graph.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Dialeski Per 3 I noticed that as well I feel it might have to do with the societal norms that took place in their time period as older people tend to not really understand why they identify themselves this way.

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Dialeski Per 3 I noticed those things as well! It is interesting that you brought up why Education was a factor in this graph as it was something I was confused and never thought about as well!

name: Angelina B
comment info:
1. Gen Z leads in the LGBTQ community and predominantly identifies with the Liberal party, living in cities. While most are non-graduates, 11% identify as Moderate or Conservative, and 17% live in Suburbs or Rural areas. Notably, 9% of LGBTQ individuals graduated from college, just 1% less than non-graduates. 
    2. I wonder if the numbers would be higher if there wasn't stigmatized to most, or due to homophobia. I wonder how many people lied about them being LGBTQ. If they live in either allows them to be more open about being LGBTQ or more into the closet. I also wonder how the ideologies change whilst being LGBTQ and residing with being Liberal, Conservative, or Moderate. I also wonder what the cause is for the 1% difference between graduates and non-graduates.
    3. Growing up in a Hispanic/black household with millennial parents and Gen X grandparents, my view of the LGBTQ+ community was influenced by their close-minded ideologies. However, as a Gen Z individual with friends and family in the community, I recognize the importance of being open-minded. In 2025, it’s crucial for everyone to feel comfortable being honest about their sexuality. Living near supportive places like New York motivates us to advocate for acceptance, ensuring our loved ones feel seen and safe. The more we show up, the stronger and prouder our community becomes.
    (Born This Way Shaped by The World: LGBTQ Identity Through a Demographic Lens0

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Angelina B --
    
    “I wonder how many people lied about them being LGBTQ. If they live in either allows them to be more open about being LGBTQ or more into the closet.”  This is called response bias – Bias caused by who askes the questions, how the questions are asked and whether people are not truthful.  You may want to look into how the survey was done.  Here’s the link --https://www.gallup.com/175307/gallup-poll-social-series-methodology.aspxI admire your honesty about your community’s views on LGBTQ+ and why you are open-minded.  Thank you for sharing your thoughts.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Angelina BI also wonder if numbers would be higher if there was less homophobia.

name: R
comment info:
The true, naturally occurring figure is around 5 per cent, according to research across cultures.
    Generations before X are lower than 5 percent because of social stigma.
    Generations after X are higher because it is cool now.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @R I also noticed that newer generations have a higher identification rate compared to older ones. Why do you think it is now considered cool?

HI, @R --
    
    What is your evidence to support “The true, naturally occurring figure is around 5 per cent, according to research across cultures.”?  Please share it.
